name: Incidence, Developed Countries
scalar_fields_json: {"maximum_value": 1, "minimum_value": 0.1, "name": "Incidence, Developed Countries", "unit": "cases per 100,000 population per year"}
raw_json: {"evidence": [{"explanation": "The incidence of invasive meningococcal disease in the Tel Aviv District falls within the range of 0.1 to 1 cases per 100,000 population per year mentioned in the statement, but it slightly exceeds the maximum value of 1 in some years.", "reference": "PMID:31495596", "snippet": "In the Tel Aviv District, the incidence rates ranged from 0.4 to 1.4 cases per 100,000 population per year during 2007-2017.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The statement is partially supported as the incidence in developed countries is generally low but can exceed the maximum value of 1 case per 100,000 population per year in some regions.", "reference": "PMID:26453240", "snippet": "Most countries had a yearly invasive NmB incidence of less than 2 per 100,000 people. Within these relatively low incidence rates (compared with common causes of invasive bacterial diseases), substantial variation was detected between countries, with a notably higher incidence in Australia, Europe, North America, and South America.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "maximum_value": 1, "minimum_value": 0.1, "name": "Incidence, Developed Countries", "unit": "cases per 100,000 population per year"}

name: Incidence, Developing Countries
notes: Higher incidence due to lower vaccination rates and crowded living conditions
scalar_fields_json: {"maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Incidence, Developing Countries", "notes": "Higher incidence due to lower vaccination rates and crowded living conditions", "unit": "cases per 100,000 population per year"}
raw_json: {"evidence": [{"explanation": "The incidence rate of bacterial meningitis in the Nottingham District Health Authority area is higher than the stated range of 1 to 10 cases per 100,000 population per year. However, this reference does not specifically address developing countries.", "reference": "PMID:8333768", "snippet": "This 10 year retrospective study of all causes of bacterial meningitis for children resident in Nottingham District Health Authority area reports an annual incidence rate per 100,000 children aged 0-16 years of 16.0 (95% confidence interval 14.0 to 18.1).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The incidence rate of Hib meningitis in Pacific island countries is significantly higher than the stated range of 1 to 10 cases per 100,000 population per year. This suggests that bacterial meningitis can have a higher incidence in certain developing regions, though it does not provide a comprehensive view across all developing countries.", "reference": "PMID:18181445", "snippet": "The Hib meningitis annual incidence in three PICs was 70 to 84 per 100,000 children under five years.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The average annual incidences for different bacterial causes of meningitis in the African meningitis belt fall within the stated range of 1 to 10 cases per 100,000 population per year, supporting the statement partially.", "reference": "PMID:31671441", "snippet": "Average annual incidences for N. meningitidis, S. pneumoniae, and H. influenzae, respectively, were 7.5, 2.5, and 0.3.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Incidence, Developing Countries", "notes": "Higher incidence due to lower vaccination rates and crowded living conditions", "unit": "cases per 100,000 population per year"}

name: Basic Reproduction Number (R0)
description: The average number of secondary infections caused by one infected individual in a completely susceptible population.
notes: Highly variable depending on environmental and population factors. Higher in areas with poor sanitation and during initial outbreak phases.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary infections caused by one infected individual in a completely susceptible population.", "maximum_value": 20, "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Basic Reproduction Number (R0)", "notes": "Highly variable depending on environmental and population factors. Higher in areas with poor sanitation and during initial outbreak phases."}
raw_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary infections caused by one infected individual in a completely susceptible population.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract discusses the use of R0 in understanding disease spread but does not detail specific values or factors affecting R0 for cholera.", "reference": "PMID:21860658", "snippet": "R(0) has been widely used as a measure of disease strength to estimate the effectiveness of control measures and to form the backbone of disease-management policy.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The abstract provides an overview of cholera's epidemiology but does not mention specific R0 values or the factors affecting R0.", "reference": "PMID:22937199", "snippet": "The two most distinguishing epidemiologic features of the disease are its tendency to appear in explosive outbreaks and its predisposition to causing pandemics.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The abstract discusses the calculation of the basic reproduction number (R0) for a cholera model but does not mention specific values or the exact factors listed.", "reference": "PMID:36654005", "snippet": "the basic reproduction number is calculated. When the basic reproduction number is less than one, the disease-free equilibrium is locally stable.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The abstract provides an estimated R0 value for cholera in Peru, mentioning spatial variability and correlation with geographic factors but not detailing all the factors listed in the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32663235", "snippet": "The overall R0 across departments was estimated at 2.1 (95% CI: 0.8, 7.3)", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The abstract discusses the R0 for COVID-19, not cholera.", "reference": "PMID:32678037", "snippet": "RESULTS: We estimated the exponential growth rate as 0.22 per day (95% CI: 0.20-0.24), and the basic reproduction number, R0, as 2.37 (95% CI: 2.22-2.51) based on the assumption that the exponential growth starting from 1 March 2020", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The abstract discusses the effect of rainfall on cholera incidence but does not provide specific R0 values or detail the factors affecting R0.", "reference": "PMID:18091420", "snippet": "The incidence of cholera in Bangladesh shows clear seasonality, suggesting that weather factors could play a role in its epidemiology.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "factors": ["Population density", "Sanitation conditions", "Water quality", "Hygiene practices"], "maximum_value": 20, "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Basic Reproduction Number (R0)", "notes": "Highly variable depending on environmental and population factors. Higher in areas with poor sanitation and during initial outbreak phases."}

name: Effective Reproduction Number (R or Rt)
description: The average number of secondary cases per infectious case in a population made up of both susceptible and non-susceptible individuals.
notes: Changes over time as control measures are implemented and population immunity increases. Rt < 1 indicates declining epidemic.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary cases per infectious case in a population made up of both susceptible and non-susceptible individuals.", "maximum_value": 8, "minimum_value": 0.5, "name": "Effective Reproduction Number (R or Rt)", "notes": "Changes over time as control measures are implemented and population immunity increases. Rt < 1 indicates declining epidemic."}
complex_fields_json: {"factors": ["Proportion of susceptible individuals", "Control measures (e.g., improved sanitation, vaccination)", "Changes in behavior (e.g., increased hygiene practices)"]}
raw_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary cases per infectious case in a population made up of both susceptible and non-susceptible individuals.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided literature discusses cholera outbreaks and prevention but does not provide specific information on the effective reproduction number (R or Rt) for cholera.", "reference": "PMID:34550374", "snippet": "Cholera outbreaks currently account for 1.3 to 4.0 million cases and cause between 21 000 and 143 000 deaths worldwide. Cholera is preventable by proper sanitization and immunization; however, in many developing nations such as India, cholera disease is endemic.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "While the literature defines the basic reproduction number for cholera, it does not provide specific values for the effective reproduction number (R or Rt) or discuss the factors affecting it.", "reference": "PMID:24245619", "snippet": "A new model for the dynamics of cholera is formulated that incorporates both the infection age of infectious individuals and biological age of pathogen in the environment. The basic reproduction number is defined and proved to be a sharp threshold determining whether or not cholera dies out.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "factors": ["Proportion of susceptible individuals", "Control measures (e.g., improved sanitation, vaccination)", "Changes in behavior (e.g., increased hygiene practices)"], "maximum_value": 8, "minimum_value": 0.5, "name": "Effective Reproduction Number (R or Rt)", "notes": "Changes over time as control measures are implemented and population immunity increases. Rt < 1 indicates declining epidemic."}

name: Serial Interval
description: The time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in secondary cases.
notes: Important for estimating R and modeling the speed of epidemic spread.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in secondary cases.", "maximum_value": 10, "mean_range": "3-5", "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Serial Interval", "notes": "Important for estimating R and modeling the speed of epidemic spread.", "unit": "days"}

reported cholera cases following a natural disaster, but does not provide information about the serial interval of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:30594260", "snippet": "To evaluate the change in reported cholera cases following Hurricane Matthew on reported cholera cases, we used interrupted time series regression models of daily reported cholera cases, controlling for the impact of both rainfall, following a 4-week lag, and seasonality, from 2013 through 2016.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "Although the reference discusses cholera transmission models, it does not provide data on the serial interval of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:36654005", "snippet": "In this paper, we consider an age-structured cholera model with saturation incidence, vaccination age of vaccinated individuals, infection age of infected individuals, and biological age of pathogens.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference addresses the impact of incubation periods on the spread and predictability of outbreaks, but does not detail the serial interval for cholera.", "reference": "PMID:32054785", "snippet": "We develop a simulation model of the spatial spread of an epidemic in order to examine the impact of a pathogen's incubation period on the dynamics of spread and the predictability of outbreaks.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study provides data on influenza epidemiology, not cholera, and does not mention serial interval.", "reference": "PMID:30114215", "snippet": "We use approximate Bayesian computation to estimate parameters in a climate-driven stochastic epidemic model, including the basic reproduction number R0.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "Although this refers to cholera research, it does not provide cholera and Vibrio cholerae (the causative bacterium of the disease), leading to major discoveries.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses real-time disease modeling with a focus on HIV/AIDS and COVID-19, not cholera.", "reference": "PMID:34995131", "snippet": "We review methods, applications, challenges and opportunities for real-time infectious disease modeling during public health emergencies, with examples drawn from the two deadliest pandemics in recent history: HIV/AIDS and coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "maximum_value": 10, "mean_range": "3-5", "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Serial Interval", "notes": "Important for estimating R and modeling the speed of epidemic spread.", "unit": "days"}

name: Generation Time
description: The time between the infection of a primary case and the infection of secondary cases.
notes: Often shorter than the serial interval due to potential pre-symptomatic transmission.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The time between the infection of a primary case and the infection of secondary cases.", "maximum_value": 9, "mean_range": "2-4", "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Generation Time", "notes": "Often shorter than the serial interval due to potential pre-symptomatic transmission.", "unit": "days"}
raw_json: {"description": "The time between the infection of a primary case and the infection of secondary cases.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature provides information about the generation time and incubation period of measles, not cholera.", "reference": "PMID:21704640", "snippet": "We have quantified a joint distribution of generation time and incubation period by a novel estimation method for household data with two susceptible individuals, consisting of time intervals between disease onsets of two measles cases.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "maximum_value": 9, "mean_range": "2-4", "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Generation Time", "notes": "Often shorter than the serial interval due to potential pre-symptomatic transmission.", "unit": "days"}

name: Infectivity Period
notes: Can be longer in asymptomatic carriers. Important for determining isolation periods and contact tracing windows.
scalar_fields_json: {"maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Infectivity Period", "notes": "Can be longer in asymptomatic carriers. Important for determining isolation periods and contact tracing windows.", "unit": "days"}
raw_json: {"evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates an average infectivity period of around 2 days, with some individuals shedding bacteria for 4 or more days, thus partially aligning with the statement's range of 1-10 days.", "reference": "PMID:25114012", "snippet": "The average length of bacterial shedding was 2.0 days (95% confidence interval 1.7-2.4). However, 16 (5%) of 294 contacts shed V. cholerae for >/= 4 days.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This estimate focuses on the incubation period rather than the entire infectivity period, providing partial support for the statement’s range of 1-10 days.", "reference": "PMID:23201968", "snippet": "We estimate the median incubation period of toxigenic cholera to be 1.4 days (95% CI, 1.3-1.6)... 95% by 4.4 days (95% CI 3.9-5.0) after infection.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The infectivity period is implied to have variability, including asymptomatic carriers, but specific durations are not explicitly detailed, offering partial support.", "reference": "PMID:37961651", "snippet": "Most infections with pandemic Vibrio cholerae are thought to result in subclinical disease and are not captured by surveillance. Previous estimates of the ratio of infections to clinical cases have varied widely (2 to 100).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 1, "name": "Infectivity Period", "notes": "Can be longer in asymptomatic carriers. Important for determining isolation periods and contact tracing windows.", "unit": "days"}

name: Attack Rate, severe
description: The proportion of susceptible individuals who become ill during a specified time interval.
notes: Varies widely depending on environmental conditions and population susceptibility.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The proportion of susceptible individuals who become ill during a specified time interval.", "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 5, "name": "Attack Rate, severe", "notes": "Varies widely depending on environmental conditions and population susceptibility.", "unit": "percentage"}
raw_json: {"description": "The proportion of susceptible individuals who become ill during a specified time interval.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature provides the median attack rate in per 1000 people, not percentages, and does not specify a range of 5%-10%. It mentions attack rates in terms of per thousand people which is not directly related to the percentages specified in the statement.", "reference": "PMID:35605949", "snippet": "The outbreak periods accounted for 1.8 billion person-months (2% of the total during this period) from January 2010 to January 2020. Among 692 outbreaks reported from second-level administrative units (e.g., districts), the median attack rate was 0.8 per 1000 people (interquartile range (IQR), 0.3-2.4 per 1000), the median epidemic duration was 13 weeks (IQR, 8-19), and the median early outbreak reproductive number was 1.8 (range, 1.1-3.5). Larger attack rates were associated with longer times to outbreak peak, longer epidemic durations, and lower case fatality risks.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses the ratio of infections to clinical cases rather than specifying the attack rate range in percentages as stated in the claim.", "reference": "PMID:37961651", "snippet": "Understanding cholera epidemiology and immunity relies on the ability to translate between numbers of clinical cases and the underlying number of infections in the population. We estimated the infection incidence during the first months of an outbreak in a cholera-naive population using a Bayesian vibriocidal antibody titer decay model combining measurements from a representative serosurvey and clinical surveillance data.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 5, "name": "Attack Rate, severe", "notes": "Varies widely depending on environmental conditions and population susceptibility.", "unit": "percentage"}

name: Prevalence range of psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers
description: Systematic review reporting wide ranges in prevalence estimates for depression, anxiety, and PTSD among family caregivers of critically ill ICU patients across studies.
notes: Ranges reported across included studies; depression 4%–94%, anxiety 2%–80%, PTSD 3%–62%.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Systematic review reporting wide ranges in prevalence estimates for depression, anxiety, and PTSD among family caregivers of critically ill ICU patients across studies.\n", "maximum_value": 94, "minimum_value": 2, "name": "Prevalence range of psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers", "notes": "Ranges reported across included studies; depression 4%–94%, anxiety 2%–80%, PTSD 3%–62%.", "unit": "percentage"}
raw_json: {"description": "Systematic review reporting wide ranges in prevalence estimates for depression, anxiety, and PTSD among family caregivers of critically ill ICU patients across studies.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This provides prevalence ranges across studies for key psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers.", "reference": "PMID:30950647", "snippet": "The prevalence of psychological outcomes in family caregivers ranged from 4% to 94% for depression, 2% to 80% for anxiety, and 3% to 62% for PTSD.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "maximum_value": 94, "minimum_value": 2, "name": "Prevalence range of psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers", "notes": "Ranges reported across included studies; depression 4%–94%, anxiety 2%–80%, PTSD 3%–62%.", "unit": "percentage"}

name: Risk factors for psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers
description: Systematic review identifying common risk factors for adverse psychological outcomes among family caregivers of critically ill ICU patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Systematic review identifying common risk factors for adverse psychological outcomes among family caregivers of critically ill ICU patients.\n", "name": "Risk factors for psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers"}
complex_fields_json: {"factors": ["Younger caregiver age", "Caregiver relationship to the patient", "Lower socioeconomic status", "Female sex"]}
raw_json: {"description": "Systematic review identifying common risk factors for adverse psychological outcomes among family caregivers of critically ill ICU patients.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review lists common risk factors associated with psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers.", "reference": "PMID:30950647", "snippet": "Common risk factors identified for adverse psychological outcomes included younger caregiver age, caregiver relationship to the patient, lower socioeconomic status, and female sex.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "factors": ["Younger caregiver age", "Caregiver relationship to the patient", "Lower socioeconomic status", "Female sex"], "name": "Risk factors for psychological outcomes in ICU family caregivers"}

name: Most common primary malignant brain tumor
description: Glioblastoma is the most common and most malignant primary brain tumor in adults.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Glioblastoma is the most common and most malignant primary brain tumor in adults.", "name": "Most common primary malignant brain tumor"}
raw_json: {"description": "Glioblastoma is the most common and most malignant primary brain tumor in adults.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This abstract explicitly identifies IDH-wildtype glioblastoma as the most common and most malignant primary brain tumor.", "reference": "PMID:41569770", "snippet": "Glioblastoma, isocitrate dehydrogenase-wildtype CNS WHO grade 4 (formerly primary glioblastoma multiforme), is the most common and most malignant primary brain tumor.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Most common primary malignant brain tumor"}

name: Basic Reproduction Number (R0)
description: The average number of secondary infections caused by one infected individual in a completely susceptible population.
notes: Highly variable based on geographic region, vaccination rates, and modes of transmission.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary infections caused by one infected individual in a completely susceptible population.", "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 2, "name": "Basic Reproduction Number (R0)", "notes": "Highly variable based on geographic region, vaccination rates, and modes of transmission."}
raw_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary infections caused by one infected individual in a completely susceptible population.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses the calculation of the basic reproduction number (R0) for Hepatitis B, which supports the statement about the importance of R0. However, it does not provide specific values for the maximum and minimum R0.", "reference": "PMID:37322965", "snippet": "In this regard, we first calculate the basic reproduction number and the equilibrium points of the deterministic Hepatitis B model.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference provides epidemiological data on Hepatitis B but does not discuss the basic reproduction number (R0) or its variability.", "reference": "PMID:16754644", "snippet": "Worldwide, two billion people have been infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV), 360 million have chronic infection, and 600,000 die each year from HBV-related liver disease or hepatocellular carcinoma.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference focuses on the determinants of transmission of bloodborne pathogens, including Hepatitis B, but does not provide information on the basic reproduction number (R0).", "reference": "PMID:7713188", "snippet": "The key determinants of transmission of bloodborne pathogens are the dose and serum viral concentration of an exposure.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "factors": ["Vaccination coverage", "Healthcare practices", "Population mobility"], "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 2, "name": "Basic Reproduction Number (R0)", "notes": "Highly variable based on geographic region, vaccination rates, and modes of transmission."}

name: Effective Reproduction Number (R or Rt)
description: The average number of secondary cases per infectious case in a population with some immunity or control measures.
notes: Decreases with effective vaccination and antiviral therapies.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary cases per infectious case in a population with some immunity or control measures.", "maximum_value": 1.2, "minimum_value": 0.3, "name": "Effective Reproduction Number (R or Rt)", "notes": "Decreases with effective vaccination and antiviral therapies."}
complex_fields_json: {"factors": ["Proportion of immune individuals", "Effectiveness of antiviral treatment"]}
raw_json: {"description": "The average number of secondary cases per infectious case in a population with some immunity or control measures.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses control strategies to reduce HBV transmission, which indirectly supports the idea that the effective reproduction number (R or Rt) decreases with effective vaccination and antiviral therapies. However, it does not provide specific values for the effective reproduction number.", "reference": "PMID:37322965", "snippet": "To reduce Hepatitis B infection rates and to promote vaccination rates, three control variables are used, for instance, isolation of patients, treatment of patients, and vaccine inoculation.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "factors": ["Proportion of immune individuals", "Effectiveness of antiviral treatment"], "maximum_value": 1.2, "minimum_value": 0.3, "name": "Effective Reproduction Number (R or Rt)", "notes": "Decreases with effective vaccination and antiviral therapies."}

name: Chronic Carriage Rate
description: The percentage of infected individuals who develop chronic hepatitis B infection.
notes: Higher in infants and young children than in adults.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The percentage of infected individuals who develop chronic hepatitis B infection.", "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 2, "name": "Chronic Carriage Rate", "notes": "Higher in infants and young children than in adults.", "unit": "percentage"}
raw_json: {"description": "The percentage of infected individuals who develop chronic hepatitis B infection.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is partially supported as it mentions that 5-10% of adults develop chronic hepatitis B infection, which falls within the 2-10% range. However, it also states that up to 90% of infants can become chronically infected, which is not captured in the statement.", "reference": "PMID:11197043", "snippet": "Of the estimated 50 million new cases of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection diagnosed annually, 5-10% of adults and up to 90% of infants will become chronically infected.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The statement is partially supported as it mentions that infants have up to 90% risk of developing chronic HBV infection, but does not provide specific percentages for adults.", "reference": "PMID:12616451", "snippet": "Infants who acquire HBV perinatally have up to 90% risk of developing chronic HBV infection.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses the role of carrier individuals in the transmission of hepatitis B but does not provide specific percentages for chronic carriage rates.", "reference": "PMID:29202763", "snippet": "Carrier individuals are especially significant, because they do not exhibit any symptoms and are able to transmit the infection.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "maximum_value": 10, "minimum_value": 2, "name": "Chronic Carriage Rate", "notes": "Higher in infants and young children than in adults.", "unit": "percentage"}

name: Asymptomatic Ratio
description: The proportion of infected individuals who do not display symptoms.
notes: Important for understanding true disease prevalence and silent spreaders.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The proportion of infected individuals who do not display symptoms.", "maximum_value": 70, "minimum_value": 50, "name": "Asymptomatic Ratio", "notes": "Important for understanding true disease prevalence and silent spreaders.", "unit": "percentage"}
raw_json: {"description": "The proportion of infected individuals who do not display symptoms.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates a high exposure rate to HBV, with a significant proportion of individuals being asymptomatic carriers. However, it does not provide a specific percentage range for asymptomatic individuals.", "reference": "PMID:23185500", "snippet": "Of 117 participants, 90% of recipients exhibited evidence of exposure to HBV, 42% with HBsAg and/or HBV DNA and 48% anti-HBc reactive without detectable HBV DNA.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions that many children with chronic HBV infection are asymptomatic, but it does not specify the exact proportion of asymptomatic cases.", "reference": "PMID:12616451", "snippet": "Many HBV-infected children have normal alanine aminotransferase values and minimal chronic hepatitis. Children with chronic HBV infection are usually asymptomatic but may develop chronic liver disease or hepatocellular carcinoma.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "maximum_value": 70, "minimum_value": 50, "name": "Asymptomatic Ratio", "notes": "Important for understanding true disease prevalence and silent spreaders.", "unit": "percentage"}

name: Age of Onset
description: Typical age range for Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome presentation
notes: Mean onset frequently in the second decade. However, cases have been reported across a wide age range from childhood to adulthood. The classic triad may not be fully apparent at disease onset, leading to delayed diagnosis.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Typical age range for Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome presentation", "maximum_value": 39, "mean_range": "Second decade of life (10-20 years)", "minimum_value": 14, "name": "Age of Onset", "notes": "Mean onset frequently in the second decade. However, cases have been reported across a wide age range from childhood to adulthood. The classic triad may not be fully apparent at disease onset, leading to delayed diagnosis.\n", "unit": "years"}

Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Establishes that granulomatous diseases including MRS have age-related presentation patterns", "reference": "PMID:29191347", "snippet": "Granulomatous diseases represent a heterogeneous group of conditions characterized by histiocytic inflammation that affect patients of any age... with particular emphasis on age-related differences in the onset, epidemiology, clinical manifestations, prognosis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "maximum_value": 39, "mean_range": "Second decade of life (10-20 years)", "minimum_value": 14, "name": "Age of Onset", "notes": "Mean onset frequently in the second decade. The classic triad may not be fully apparent at disease onset, leading to delayed diagnosis.\n", "unit": "years"}

name: Incidence Rate
description: Annual incidence of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome in the general population
notes: Wide variability in reported incidence rates (0.2–80 per 100,000/year) depending on population studied, diagnostic criteria, and case finding methodology. Higher rates may reflect increased awareness and diagnostic recognition. Diagnostic underrecognition and delayed diagnosis are common, particularly when only monosymptomatic variants (e.g., isolated cheilitis) are present.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Annual incidence of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome in the general population", "maximum_value": 80, "minimum_value": 0.2, "name": "Incidence Rate", "notes": "Wide variability in reported incidence rates (0.2–80 per 100,000/year) depending on population studied, diagnostic criteria, and case finding methodology. Higher rates may reflect increased awareness and diagnostic recognition. Diagnostic underrecognition and delayed diagnosis are common, particularly when only monosymptomatic variants (e.g., isolated cheilitis) are present.\n", "unit": "per 100,000 per year"}

Higher rates may reflect increased awareness and diagnostic recognition. Diagnostic underrecognition and delayed diagnosis are common, particularly when only monosymptomatic variants (e.g., isolated cheilitis) are present.\n", "unit": "per 100,000 per year"}

name: Frequency of Complete Triad
description: Percentage of MRS patients presenting with all three features of the classic triad
notes: Only 8–25% of MRS cases present with the complete classic triad (recurrent orofacial edema, facial nerve paralysis, fissured tongue). Many patients present with monosymptomatic or oligosymptomatic variants, particularly isolated granulomatous cheilitis, leading to diagnostic delays.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Percentage of MRS patients presenting with all three features of the classic triad", "maximum_value": 25, "minimum_value": 8, "name": "Frequency of Complete Triad", "notes": "Only 8–25% of MRS cases present with the complete classic triad (recurrent orofacial edema, facial nerve paralysis, fissured tongue). Many patients present with monosymptomatic or oligosymptomatic variants, particularly isolated granulomatous cheilitis, leading to diagnostic delays.\n", "unit": "percent"}
raw_json: {"description": "Percentage of MRS patients presenting with all three features of the classic triad", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms that the complete triad occurs in only a minority of MRS cases", "reference": "PMID:31466978", "snippet": "This case is particularly rare, as the classic triad is seen only in a minority of the cases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Demonstrates that monosymptomatic presentations (isolated cheilitis) are common, with only a minority presenting with the complete triad", "reference": "PMID:22657098", "snippet": "Granulomatous cheilitis (Miescher cheilitis)... is the most common monosymptomatic form of the Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "maximum_value": 25, "minimum_value": 8, "name": "Frequency of Complete Triad", "notes": "Only 8–25% of MRS cases present with the complete classic triad (recurrent orofacial edema, facial nerve paralysis, fissured tongue). Many patients present with monosymptomatic or oligosymptomatic variants, particularly isolated granulomatous cheilitis, leading to diagnostic delays.\n", "unit": "percent"}

name: Sex distribution in imaging cohort
description: Male predominance reported in a cardiothoracic imaging cohort.
notes: In a cohort of 38 imaged individuals, 23 were men.

raw_json: {"description": "Male predominance reported in a cardiothoracic imaging cohort.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This cohort reports a male-predominant sex distribution among imaged individuals.", "reference": "DOI:10.1038/s41598-021-86029-0", "snippet": "Of 53 individuals with a confirmed diagnosis of Proteus syndrome at our institution from 10/2001 to 10/2019, 38 individuals (men, n = 23; average age = 24 years) underwent cardiothoracic imaging", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Sex distribution in imaging cohort", "notes": "In a cohort of 38 imaged individuals, 23 were men.", "unit": "cases"}

name: Limited number of reported long-term survivors
description: Published reports note that only a small number of cases have been followed into the second decade, highlighting the rarity of long-term survival data.
notes: Evidence is based on case-report literature rather than population estimates.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Published reports note that only a small number of cases have been followed into the second decade, highlighting the rarity of long-term survival data.\n", "name": "Limited number of reported long-term survivors", "notes": "Evidence is based on case-report literature rather than population estimates."}
raw_json: {"description": "Published reports note that only a small number of cases have been followed into the second decade, highlighting the rarity of long-term survival data.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This statement indicates the scarcity of long-term follow-up and limited reported cases.", "reference": "DOI:10.1186/s13052-022-01370-y", "snippet": "Thus far few reported cases have survived the second decade at their latest examination, and no natural history data are available for the disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Limited number of reported long-term survivors", "notes": "Evidence is based on case-report literature rather than population estimates."}
